page.title: 14THE BRIDGE AT NEWBRIDGE
page.content: Although the present bridge was not built until{1450,}the site has been an important{fording point}over the River Lynher since Neolithic times. In the 11th century it marked the{boundary}between Celtic and Saxon Britain. The bridge today retains its 15th century form, with massive{piers}of granite and moorstone and 4 round {arches,}each 12 foot in span. However, it was partially rebuilt in{1698}and widened by 5 feet on the southern side in{1874. Brackets}remain projecting on the northern side of the bridge from the days when a stake net was attached for Rillaton Fishery. Since 1450, Newbridge has seen the passage of the 1st Exeter to Truro coach in{1600,}King Charles and his army in{1643}and the 1st Liskeard to Callington mail service in the{1790's.
